TEXT: (Interpreted).
Ladies and gentlemen, good morning.
Good morning.
We're delighted as always to have you this morning with Christophe Cros.
We are going to present the 2015 annual results for Suez.
First of all, I would like to thank those of you who came this morning and I would like to remind you that this presentation will be available through the webcast.
You will be able to download it as well from the Group's -- the Company's website.
Before getting started and commenting on the Company's performance, I would like to remind you that the Suez's activities is trying to address the challenges of this century.
We are very much engaged in the resource revolution.
During COP21, all players, both civil society, the corporate world were mobilized.
It was a turning point, a decisive event, during which Suez was actively present.
We're very proud to take part and feel that we can fully contribute by addressing the challenges of today's world with some of our technologies and solutions in order to save our planet.
My presentation will be as follows.
We will start off by a presentation on the 2015 performance.
And I can say that we are quite satisfied because we reached, even outperformed, our objectives.
This performance is based primarily on progress made by the Company in the commercial area.
We had a number of successes around the globe.
The results are remarkable, especially given the fact that the global context has been much more complicated than initially anticipated at the beginning of 2015.
Good morning.
As for 2016, well, I feel confident.
I feel confident because Suez is a very well-balanced company.
However, I think we have to become more vigilant.
There are uncertainties, geopolitical uncertainties, emerging countries, the production crisis in Europe, and we have to remain cautious.

And for that reason, we've decided to accelerate the transformation of Suez to make it a more integrated company, to make it a company able to address sustainable requirements and needs and manage resources in a more sustainable way going forward.
I will wrap up by giving you an overview of our financial performance for 2015.
So, before diving into the figures, I would like to come back to one important component of Suez's transformation throughout 2015.
The name, as you know, the name is now shared by all.
In the past we had 40 different brands.
And this is a significant sign of progress.
And we're now an integrated company and it is a sign for more collaboration between the employees.
And it is a sign as well of progress for our customers.
Since March 2015 we have all become ambassadors of the Suez brand and we are all firmly committed to become a benchmark in the industry.
Our visibility for the outside world has been significantly improved and increased, and we are already seeing benefits with recently signed contracts.
I would like to comment on two important external growth that happened in 2015.
As you know, with the Chongqing authorities in China, we have an agreement.
This is a company which is active in both water and waste treatment.
It is a very active region, the Sichuan region.
But it's not limited to that region only.
It's very active throughout China and in the region.
Another important operation is minority buyback of an Australian company, and with very good financial conditions.
And with this, we're going to be able to deploy an integration strategy which is the same strategy we've deployed around the globe.
This is the integration of our two activities, water and waste.
And we're going to obtain synergies both in terms of cost and from the commercial standpoint.
Regarding the financial performance in 2015, well, I can confirm that we have stuck to all our commitments.
We were able to improve the Company's profitability.
EBITDA is up 4.1%.
EBIT is up more than 10%.
And our net income Group share is EUR408m.
Free cash flow, which is a very important indicator, as you know, is above EUR1,047m, Christophe will comment on this.
And our financial flexibility has remained excellent with our net debt over EBITDA is 2.9 times.
We're going to ask the general assembly to pay a dividend of EUR0.65 per share.
So you will agree with me that these results are very satisfactory, once again, in a context which I would describe as complex.
We'll come back to this throughout the presentation.
Taking a look at the next slide, you will see what the -- where the commercial successes are coming from for 2015.
This is true for the entire Group and all the divisions.
Investment decisions are made centrally, however, our commercial policies are very much local.
So the 2015 success stories are the success stories of the people out there in the field.
I can't go through all the contracts.
Let me just give you a few starting off with water in France.
I'm very happy, very proud of the development of our new services.
An illustration of this would be the decarbonation, which is a way to soften water, with the Gennevilliers municipality, we have a contract.
We renewed the contract, which is a public delegation contract.
The value is EUR639m over a 12-year period.
We were also able to get the contract for water supply, so this is de-carbonated water supply, we have a EUR234m contract.
This is 15-year contract, to improve the quality of water, to secure the water supply to over 600,000 citizens living in the Gennevilliers area.

What is interesting with this new contract is that it perfectly illustrates the trust, how much our customers trust us, and our ability to roll out technologies, technological innovations, including in areas where we have operated for many years.
In waste, I would like to come back to the Covaldem 11 contract.
This is a contract which covers seven municipalities, including the Municipality of Carcassonne.
Total amount is EUR459m over a 19-year period.

It's a very innovative partnership, which brings together civil society and municipalities with a new governance model, which I would describe as the collective collaborative model, with different stakeholders, including Board level.
This is how this new partnership contract will be managed.
With this contract, we're going to become better at optimizing waste.
And the overall rate, reuse rate, will be much better than what we have so far.
So this is going to generate additional turnover, and once again, it illustrates that as a company we are becoming increasingly innovative.
This is the first contract, public service delegation contract.
We've never had anything like this in waste.
We've had it in incineration, but this is not an incineration contract.
It's a different contract.
So, another contract, another deal I would like to comment is -- as you can see, first of all, we've reinforced our positions across the globe.
This is very much the case in Asia.
China, as you can see, is a very promising and strong market.

The authorities are increasingly seeking to give a priority to environmental questions, and we have a new contract to pick up a 30-year contract for -- in Changshu for a, which is an industrial park, for wastewater treatment.
This makes it the 11th -- it's the 11th biggest wastewater treatment facility in China.
And it's an interesting contract because it's an area where chemical operators, chemical industries and fluoride is being processed and treated.
The last contract is the contract we picked up with Sanofi.
I've commented on this contract during the announcement of our half-year results.
And we -- there are additional contracts as well.
We have a multi-site contract which we just signed with Safran.
This is a EUR10m contract for a maximum length of five years.
And it includes waste management as well as treatment facility management for 11 sites.
Suez is -- will be identifying progress opportunities to better manage waste, waste reuse, metals, oils, wood, cardboard, plastic.
And we will significantly contribute to the company's footprint, Safran's footprint.
This is a beautiful example of a partnership and industrial partnership where Suez is providing all its experience and knowhow to a large company, Safran.
And as you probably know, we've had a joint venture with Safran and Airbus with tarmac near the city of Tarbes.
So these examples show how important it is to have industrial partnerships and how we've been able to address the needs of -- different needs of our customers.
So, once again the competitive environment has become more complex in the meantime.

No one anticipated 2015 would be such a complicated year with the geopolitical changes, a number of crises in Brazil, in Russia, for example, deflation in Western countries, world growth which is slower than expected, especially influenced by the slowdown of the Chinese economy and of course with the drop of raw -- in the price of raw materials.
The outlook is still pretty negative with some of our private and public customers in a number of developed countries.
And again, as I said, competition has become more complex with newcomers.
A number of Asian companies are starting to do business in the Middle East, for example, and they're now also interested in Europe, of course.
And a lot of the big players are restructuring in order to meet the new challenges.
In 2015, our activities were positively impacted by weather in France, in Spain, and even in Chile, with volumes sold above long-term averages, expected averages.
So you will agree, the economic context was not very favorable, and this was of course very much the case in France as well.
The level of industrial production in France is still behind what we had in 2008, whereas countries like Germany have really managed to catch up since the subprime crisis.
And there's more and more concern about risks, both with industrial companies and municipalities.
People are -- have become a lot more sensitive to [debt].
Therefore, investments have contracted.
Again this is very much the case with private companies as well as municipalities, people are very cautious and are giving priority to short term.
The competitive landscape hasn't really changed in France, but there is more and more pressure on margins in order to remain competitive.
